snippet: The epidemic has exposed gaping holes in the ability to tackle outbreaks in an increasingly interconnected world, where diseases can quickly spread from remote villages to cities housing millions of people.
abstract: World Health Organization has experienced severe budget cuts, hobbling its ability to take control of West Africa's Ebola epidemic; its emergency response and outbreak units have been slashed, veterans who led previous fights against Ebola and other diseases have left, and scores of positions have been eliminated; WHO's road map calls for $490 million from donors, and thousands of foreign and local health workers to contain the Ebola outbreak, and few have answered those calls.
lead_paragraph: The epidemic has exposed gaping holes in the ability to tackle outbreaks in an increasingly interconnected world, where diseases can quickly spread from remote villages to cities housing millions of people.

headline.main: Cuts at W.H.O. Hurt Response to Ebola Crisis
